author: @brookshanson5230
text: For anyone struggling with making your charts interactive in Spyder or VS Code like sentdex is doing in IDLE, try the following: Spyder: Change the backend to automatic:  Tools > preferences > IPython console > Graphics > Graphics backend > Backend: Automatic  Then close and open Spyder. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23585126/how-do-i-get-interactive-plots-again-in-spyder-ipython-matplotlib  VS Code: Install and import ipympl via conda or pip run:  %matplotlib auto   before you show your plots https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55693457/is-there-a-way-to-open-graphs-in-a-new-window-in-vscode  Hope this helps!

author: @justjoy7179
text: The moving average found in the video is, I beleive is calculated wrong. It is because the data in csv file is such that head denotes the end date while tail denotes the start date. So when you find moving average above, you get NaN in the first 99 entities(from head) while beyond that you get the desired numbers(till tail). But in real case, we need moving average from the present date, which means, we require moving average of dates from the very first date of head side while we should be getting NaN for last 99 dates on tail side. Example lets say we take data such that  start =(2019,1,1) end = (2019,1,30) thus head of our table would be 30 Jan 2019 and tail would be 1 Jan 2019. Now if we find ma for, say, 10 days, by your method, we would be getting NaN for 9 days (which is 21 Jan to 30 Jan) and then we would be getting numbers for rest. The point I am trying to make is if we need to use this method for real analysis purpose, we will have to invert the data, right? If yes, is there a easy way...as i tried swapping start and end, but didn't work out. [lets assume we have data of all 30 days with us, although in real we dont't due to Sat. and Sun.]   Please explain it if I am wrong...I am confused!!

author: @soumen_das
text: Anyone using pandas 0.21.0 will get this error  TypeError: ufunc subtract cannot use operands with types dtype('<M8[ns]') and dtype('float64') To resolve it add the following to your code:  from pandas.tseries import converter as pdtc import matplotlib.units as munits import numpy as np  munits.registry[np.datetime64] = pdtc.DatetimeConverter()

author: @babakbandpey
text: If you receive error on: df['100ma'] = df['Adj Close'].rolling(window=100).mean() replace it with: df['100ma'] = df['Close'].rolling(window=100).mean() The 'Adj Close' is the name of a column in the data-file which might be missing in your case, or just use the name of another numerical column, which means any column except the date column.  Thanks for tutorial too friend

author: @hareshkhambhadiya7041
text: Code: import datetime as dt import pandas as pd  df= pd.read_csv('data/IOC.csv', index_col=False) df = df.head(200) df['30ma']=  df ['Adj Close'].rolling(window=30, min_periods=0) .mean() df['50ma']=  df ['Adj Close'].rolling(window=50, min_periods=0) .mean()  df['100ma']=  df ['Adj Close'].rolling(window=100, min_periods=0) .mean() df['150ma']=  df ['Adj Close'].rolling(window=150, min_periods=0) .mean()                                                                                                                         df['200ma']=  df ['Adj Close'].rolling(window=200, min_periods=0) .mean()                                                                       df.to_csv('out.csv', index = False)  Output: Date,Open,High,Low,Close,Volume,Adj Close,30ma,50ma,100ma,150ma,200ma 2017-03-17,379.0,379.4,374.5,375.85,3301500,375.85,375.85,375.85,375.85,375.85,375.85 2017-03-16,374.0,377.0,371.0,376.15,3362100,376.15,376.0,376.0,376.0,376.0,376.0 2017-03-15,374.15,374.5,368.6,369.75,4816000,369.75,373.916666667,373.916666667,373.916666667,373.916666667,373.916666667 2017-03-14,379.0,379.1,372.3,374.0,3495100,374.0,373.9375,373.9375,373.9375,373.9375,373.9375  Question: code run successfully but why value is same for 30ma, 50ma, 100ma, 150ma, 200ma?
